Faculty of Chemical and Metallurgical Engineering İstanbul Technical University Maslak İstanbul 34469 Turkey The effects of precipitant and solid basicity on the Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS) activity of the sodium doped zinc ferrite catalysts were investigated. Olefin selectivity and stability of the catalysts were interrelated with the solid basicity which varied with the type of the precipitant, the amount of alkali promoter and its incorporation way into the catalyst matrix. The type of the precipitant and ionic medium of hydrolysis were seen to affect the textural properties of zinc ferrites. A cubic spinel phase of ZnFe2O4 were observed for all catalysts. Sodium promoter significantly modified the reduction behavior of the samples as well. Since the ionic strength was believed to have an effect on the solubility constants of Fe(OH)3 and Zn(OH)2, the purity of ZnFe2O4 nanoparticles would be expected to change as to be noticed from their different TPR profiles. All zinc ferrite samples had a much smaller crystal size than the precipitated iron, showing the structural promoter effect of zinc. In the study, the basicity of the catalysts was also correlated with FTS activity. All alkali promoted zinc ferrite catalysts have shown high olefin selectivity of about 50%. Although a basicity of certain extent is a must to attain high olefin selectivity, coking seems inevitable at high basicity. Therefore, an optimum interaction strength of the surface for CO dissociation appeared to exist and it might be tuned by surface basicity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Zinc ferrite catalyst Na promoter Light olefin Co-precipitation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Light olefins are petrochemical building block chemicals which are used as intermediates for production of polymers, plastics, detergents, and solvents. The applications of olefins are numerous and increasing demands for plastics necessitates a sustainable olefin supply. Olefins are conventionally produced by the steam cracking (SC) of naphta [1]. However, fossil fuel reserves are depleting and there is a rapid rise in CO2 emissions that motivates alternative non-oil-based feedstock routes including use of wastes and biomass. These routes can be mainly classified as: methanol to olefins (MTO) and Fischer–Tropsch synthesis to olefins (FTSO) [2,3]. Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is a catalytic process that allows the production of synthetic fuels and chemicals from a carbon monoxide-hydrogen mixture called syngas. The whole process is counted to be sustainable and green if the biomass is used as feedstock for syngas generation. Although Fischer-Tropsch synthesis is a well-known process for about a century, there is still a need for research in the field to address some problems that remain up to date e.g. direct production of light olefins. Catalyst is the most critical component for an efficient and commercial scale light olefin production through FTS. Catalysts are required to tune the selectivity towards light olefins by altering the chain growth and limiting the secondary hydrogenation reactions. Fe, Co, Ni, Ru and Os are the most widely used catalytic materials in FTS. It is reported that Re and Rh also show acceptable catalytic activity for FTS [4]. However, Fe- and Co-based catalysts are the most used ones. Fe-based catalysts are more reactive to water-gas shift (WGS) reaction, making them ideal when syngas obtained from coal and biomass gasfication has low H2 to CO ratio,. Moreover, iron exhibits high selectivity towards to olefins [5–7]. The catalytic behavior of iron catalysts can be improved by the use of transition (Zn, Cu, Ru) and alkali (K, Na, Cs, Rb) metals added as promoters. These metals can act as structural or chemical promoters to enhance the metal dispersion and facilitate the iron oxide reduction by stabilization of iron against oxidation [8,9]. It is believed that alkali metals can affect the catalytic performance by decreasing the strength of C-O bonds leading to an increase in the CO dissociation [10–12]. Alkali promoters make the iron catalysts to gain additional features such as suppression of the secondary hydrogenation, facilitated light olefins desorption and increased chain growth probability [11,13,14]. These features provide high olefin to paraffin ratio and C5+ selectivity at the expense of low carbon paraffins. From Group I alkali metals I, effect of K and Na have been widely investigated [10–12]. Iron carbides are believed to be the most active catalyticphase in FTS [18]. Alkali metals, e.g. Na, extend the carburization of iron oxides. However, an optimum alkali concentration is believed to exist beyond which coking apparently dominates [13,14]. Apart from the need for active iron carbide formation, preserving the active surface area is the other concern for an acceptable light olefin selectivity. Transition metals are employed as a structural promoters of iron carbides. In this context, the effect of Zn on Fe-based catalysts have been investigated [13,15–26]. Their use in an appropriate proportion may inhibit sintering [24]. Effects of Zn, Cu and K on the structure and catalytic behavior of iron-based FTS catalyst were studied by Li et al. [13]. In case of Zn use, it was shown that spinel-type zinc ferrite structure appears along with hematite. They have argued its structural promoter effect for changing Zn concentrations. The observed inhibited sintering of Fe2O3 was ascribed to the formation of small ZnFe2O4 crystallites at low Zn concentration while ZnFe2O4 crystallites at high Zn concentration was seen as a matrix for the isolation of Fe2O3 [13]. Choi et al. [20] reported that Na-promoted spinel zinc ferrite was highly selective to liquid-fuels, as high as 58% and observed a high olefin/paraffin ratio of up to 11 for CO2 hydrogenation. In a study of bimetallic interactions of iron and zinc by Wang et al. [25], it was found that when ZnFe2O4 was formed, the stability and activity of the catalyst increased due to the enhanced dispersion of active sites. The type of the precipitant and the precipitation method are the other primary concerns which determine the final catalytic activity since they may change the nature of iron oxy-hydroxides formed during precipitation [26]. Effects of various precipitants on FTO performance of Fe/Zn catalysts have been investigated by Zhao et al. [27]. The catalysts precipitated with sodium carbonate displayed higher selectivity towards light olefins compared to those precipitated with potassium carbonate and ammonium carbonate. They reported a 95% CO conversion and a 53% light olefin selectivity for the FeZn catalyst with Fe/Zn molar ratio = 1 and 1.86 wt% Na. Na-promoted FeZn1.2Ox catalysts have been synthesized and investigated for their FTS performance at 340 °C and 2.0 MPa by Yang et al. [23]. They suggested that the presence of Na retards the reduction of Fe1Zn1.2Ox while facilitate the Fe5C2 formation. A CO conversion of 76.7 % and olefin selectivity of 29.2% were obtained with Na0.2/ Fe1Zn1.2Ox which was calcined at 400 °C. Consequently, structural effect of Zn and electronic effect of Na on iron catalyst might be utilized in order to get high activity and selectivity towards light olefins [20,28]. Previous studies revealed that presence of Zn and Na can influence the structure and electronic configuration of the Fe-based FTS catalysts, respectively. Therefore, these elements may be used to increase the activity and selectivity of the catalysts towards light olefins. However, their optimum combinations and incorporation routes into catalyst matrix still need further investigation. The objective of this work is to investigate the effect of precipitant and solid basicity on the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis activity of Fe-Zn catalysts. Solid basicity of the catalysts was modified by changing the type of the precipitant, the amount of alkali promoter and its incorporation way to the catalyst matrix. The resultant catalysts were investigated for their light olefin selectivity and stability. The catalysts were characterized by BET surface area, X-ray diffraction (XRD), inductively coupled plasma (ICP-OES), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), H2-TPR and CO2-TPD analyzes. The relation between performance and structural properties of the catalysts was assessed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2Fe.Zn catalysts have been prepared first by co-precipitation method using NH4OH (AH) as precipitant. Sodium has been incorporated into the 2Fe.Zn precipitate by different routes; use of sodium nitrate during co-precipitation (AH route) or its subsequent impregnation on co-precipitated 2Fe.Zn catalyst (AH-I route). Alternatively, Na2CO3 (SC) was employed instead of NH4OH (AH) for precipitation in order to investigate the effect of precipitant type (SC route). Then this base precipitate 2Fe.Zn (SC) with changing final washing cycles was impregnated with sodium (SC-I route). The chemicals, Fe(NO3)3.9H2O (Merck, ACS grade), Zn(NO3)2.6H2O (Sigma, ACS grade), NaNO3(Sigma, ACS grade), NH4OH (Sigma, 25–30% NH3 basis) and Na2CO3 (Sigma, ACS grade) were used in the synthesis of catalysts. Nine catalysts have been synthesized. In the first synthesis method (AH route), Fe: Zn: Na: NH4: H2O molar ratios of the precipitation bath were 2: 1: 0: 9.6: 246, 2: 1: 0.2: 9.9: 252 and 2: 1: 0.4: 10.1: 259 for the precipitation of 2Fe.Zn(AH), 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH) and 2Fe.Zn0.4Na (AH), respectively. For the precipitation, the mixture of metal salts (Fe(NO3)3.9H2O, Zn(NO3)2.6H2O, NaNO3) were dissolved in deionized water and kept at 80 °C under continuous stirring at 400–500 rpm. Then, ammonium hydroxide (AH) in 30% NH3 solution was added into the stirred solution at 80 °C in dropwise until the pH of the solution was stabilized between 7 and 8. This was complete in 20 min. Then the precipitate was filtered with a filter paper, MN 640 DE Ø 125 mm. The pore size of the filter paper was 2–4 µm. The precipitate then was washed by deionized water for several times and dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight. Dry catalysts were calcined under a 35 ml/min dry air flow at 400 °C for 2 h. Heating ramp to calcination temperature was 5 °C/min. Prepared catalysts were denoted as 2Fe.Zn(AH), 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH), and 2Fe.Zn0.4Na(AH). In the second synthesis method (AH-I route), the base catalyst 2Fe.Zn(AH) was impregnated with NaNO3 solution. Upon impregnation with Na, the catalysts were dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight. Then, the catalysts were calcined at 400 °C for 2 h under a dry air flow of 35 ml/min. So-prepared catalysts were labelled with 2Fe.Zn0.1Na (AH-I), and 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH-I) based on the sodium content of the starting impregnation batch (molar ratios of 2FeZnxNa, x=0.1 and 0.2). To investigate the effect of precipitant, sodium carbonate (SC) was used in place of ammonium hydroxide (AH). 2Fe.Zn was first co-precipitated with sodium carbonate. In the synthesis via SC route, Fe: Zn: Na: NH4: H2O molar ratios of the precipitation were 2: 1: 10.6: 369. It took 30 min to complete the dropwise addition of SC. Then the precipitate was filtered and washed with deionized water in the same way with AH route. Washing was a critical step for the sodium based precipitants since the amount of residual sodium in the catalysts decreased with the increasing washing cycles. The high level of washing was required to reduce the residual Na left in the base catalysts to trace amounts. The criterion used to decide whether the washing was effective or complete was pH of the resulting solutions of the precipitate's washing. It was targeted to attain a pH = 6-7 to ensure the complete removal of sodium cations. To investigate the effect of washing efficiency on residual sodium content, three sets of base catalysts with different washing levels were prepared. For the thoroughly washing case, which was expected to lead the least sodium content, the catalyst was washed with 1800 ml water and denoted as 2Fe.Zn (SC) or base catalyst. In the other cases, 1200 and 600 ml water were used for washing to obtain precipitates with moderate and high residual sodium contents, respectively. Then the same amount of sodium salt promotor was subsequently impregnated on each of these precipitates. The base catalyst, 2Fe.Zn (SC), was impregnated with sodium nitrate in an amount corresponding to an initial Fe:Zn:Na molar ratio of 2:1:0.2 and denoted as 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1. The catalysts with two and three times less final washing cycles were also impregnated with the same amount of sodium and denoted as 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)2 and 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)3, respectively. In order to investigate the structural promotion effect of Zn for 2Fe.Zn catalyst, pure Fe( without Zn) was also precipitated by ammonium hydroxide and the resulted catalyst was denoted as Fe (AH). The prepared catalysts are given in Table 1 . 2.2 Catalyst characterization Brunauer-Emmett-Teller analysis (BET) based on N2-adsorption at 77 K in a Micromeritics 3 Flex analyzer was performed to measure the surface areas, pore volumes and pore sizes of the catalysts. Before taking adsorption isotherms, all samples were degassed at 150 °C for 24 h under vacuum. The pore volume and average pore size distribution were calculated as well by Barret–Joyner–Hallender (BJH) method. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Optical 2100 DV) was used to determine the chemical composition of the catalysts. The effect of washing cycles on residual alkali content for the catalysts prepared by SC-I route was checked by chemical analysis as well. For chemical analysis, the catalysts samples were first digested into the solution of HNO3 and HCl by microwave instrument (Multiwave PRO, Multiwave 3000). The bulk crystalline structures of the fresh and the spent catalysts were determined at 40 kV and 30 mA in between 10 and 700 with a step size of 0.0167 0 by X-ray diffraction (XRD, PANanalytical/X pert Pro) using CuKα radiation (λ=0.15405 nm). Crystallite sizes of fresh catalysts were calculated by Scherrer equation D = (Kxλ)/(dcosθ), where K=0.9, λ = 0.15406, 2θ=35.5o and d = The full width at half maximum (FWHM) based on the strongest diffraction peak at 35.5°. The amount of carbon deposited on the spent catalyst was determined by Vario MACRO cube Analyzer using ASTM D 4239-12 method. Reducibility behavior of catalysts were determined by the H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) in a fixed bed reactor. In TPR measurements, first, 0.15 g of catalyst was preheated in a N2 flow at 350 °C for 30 min. Then, the reactor temperature was first decreased to 50 °C and increased to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 under a 80 mL h−1 hydrogen-nitrogen mixture (10v% H2 in balance N2). Data were collected by both an on-line micro GC (Inficon, micro GC Fusion) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and an on-line mass spectrometer (MS) (Stanford Research Systems, RGA 200). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were taken by TESCAN VEGA 3 SBH. Prior to each analysis, all catalyst samples were pretreated by coating with Au-Pd. SEM images with elemental mapping (SEM-EDS) given in supplementary information were taken byThermofisher ChemiSEM Axia to probe the morphological changes of the samples with no pre-coating. The surface basicity of the samples was determined by the CO2-temperature programmed desorption in the same system used for H2-TPR analyses. In CO2-TPD analyses, 0.15 mg catalyst was thermally treated and reduced under 53 mL min−1H2 flow for 2 h at 350 °C. Then catalysts were purged with a 100 mL N2 for 30 min at 350 °C. Afterward, temperature was reduced to 50 °C. The CO2 adsorption was conducted with a 100 mL min−1 gas miture of 5%CO2 and 95% He at 50 °C for 30 min. Then physisorbed CO2 was swept away by a 100 mL min−1N2 for 30 min. In the desorption step of chemisorbed CO2, the temperature was increased from 50 to 800 °C with a ramp of 10 °C min−1 under 100 mL min−1 N2 flow. The CO2 desorption profiles were obtained through detecting the desorbed amount of CO2 at corresponding desorption temperature by a micro GC and a MS. 2.3 Catalytic tests Fischer-Tropsch reaction was conducted in a high pressure test system equipped with a fixed bed reactor (i.d.: 10 mm; length: 800 mm). The temperature of the reactor was monitored by a thermocouple which was insurted into the catalyst bed. Output lines of the reactor are heat in order to prevent any condensation. Catalytic activity tests were performed by using 1 g catalyst with a particle size of 50–150 microns which was diluted with quartz particles having the same particle size range and in equivalent volume to prevent hot spots. Prior to the reaction, calcined catalysts were reduced with a gas mixture composed of 50v%H2 -50v%N2 at 350 ⁰C for 2 h at atmospheric pressure. Subsequently, the reactor was set to reaction conditions, namely 310 °C and 10 bar. FT reaction was performed with a 50 mL min−1 flow of 60v% H2 / 30v% CO / 10v% N2. The product gas was quantitatively analyzed in every 30 min by an on-line gas chromatography (Agilent, 7820A GC). The amounts of H2, CO, CO2, and N2 were detected by thermal conductivity detector (TCD) with a Carboxen column. C1-C5+ hydrocarbons were detected by a flame ionization detector (FID) with Alumina S column. Molar flow rate of CO at inlet and outlet were calculated with Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively. Catalyst performance was determined based on the CO conversion (XCO) in Eq. (3), the CO2 -free hydrocarbon selectivity on carbon basis (Scn) in Eq. (4), the CO2 selectivity on carbon basis (XCO2) in Eq. (5) and olefin/paraffin molar ratio in was Eq. (6). In the following equations, “in” and “out” denote inlet and outlet of the reactor. (1) C O i n = F i n × C O e n t r y (2) C O o u t = F o u t × C O e x i t (3) X C O = ( C O i n − C O o u t ) ( C O i n ) × 100 (4) Hydrocarbon Selectivity ( C basis ) , S c n = n C × F o u t × x n ( HC ) ( C O i n − C O o u t ) − C O 2 out × 100 (5) X C O 2 = C O 2 o u t ( C O i n − C O o u t ) × 100 (6) Olefin / paraffin = ∑ 2 4 C = ∑ 2 4 C 0 where Fin is the molar flow rate of feed gas stream (mole/h), Fout is the molar flow rate of product gas stream (mol/h), COin is the molar flow rate of CO at inlet (mol/h) and COout is the molar flow rate of CO at outlet (mol/h), Xn (HC) is the mole fraction of the hydrocarbon in the product stream, nC is the carbon number of the hydrocarbon whose selectivity is calculated and CO2out denotes the moles flow rate of CO2 at outlet (mol/h). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The actual elemental analysis of each catalyst sample and actual Fe/Zn/Na molar ratios of the catalysts calculated were given in Table 2 . All the catalysts were precipitated initially with the same synthesis batch in which iron and zinc salts existed in stoichiometric amounts for zinc ferrite structure (Fe to Zn molar ratio of 2). However, the precipitation bath contained different precipitant ions of NH4 +, OH−, Na+, NO3 −, CO3 2− and in different concentrations. Therefore, ionic strength might affect the ultimate Fe/Zn ratio of the catalysts since concentration dependent interactions between ions bring non-ideality by moving from dilute solutions to concentrates. In this term, concentrations can be substantially different depending on the ionic equilibria as a feature of ionic strength of the solution. The electrolyte precipitate solution attains different ionic strength and ionic radius in each case which may lead to altered solubility and precipitation phenomenon. As it was reported in Table 2, when AH was used as precipitant, the ultimate Fe/Zn ratios of the catalysts changed between ⁓2.3 and 3.0. On the other hand, when SC was used as precipitant, the Fe/Zn ratio decreased to ⁓ 1.85–1.89 which was much closer to the stoichiometric ratio of zinc ferrite structure. These results suggest that iron oxide compounds may be found in the 2Fe.Zn(AH) catalyst composition, apart from the zinc ferrite structure depending on the type of the precipitant. When Na contents of the catalysts precipitated with sodium carbonate were examined, it was noticed that ∼0.5% of sodium in the final catalyst 2Fe.Zn (SC) composition came from the sodium content of the precipitant. Depending on washing level, the concentration of the residual sodium left over in the precipitate varied. For example, while 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1, 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)2, and 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)3 all have the same amount of sodium impregnation, their final sodium contents were quite different. Well washed sample, 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1, had the least sodium content, namely 2.59%. However, a much higher sodium content of 5.6% was measured for the 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)3catalyst, whic was exposed to a quite poor washing. As long as the washing step eliminates all the residual sodium coming from the precipitant, the sodium content of the catalyst got close to the actual amount of sodium used for its impragnation. The comparison of 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH-I) and 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1 has verified the effect of washing on the residual sodium. 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH-I) and 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1 catalysts were precipitated in the absence and presence of sodium cation, respectively. Thanks to a good washing process, sodium content of 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1 was mostly due to impregnation. The second point that should be remarked here is that when sodium was incorporated into the precipitation batch instead of impregnation, less sodium was fixed to the final catalyst matrix. For example, 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH) had less sodium than 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH-I). This was in accordance with the fact that most of the sodium was removed during the filtration of the precipitate. However, since ionic medium of iron hydrolysis affected the composition of the hydrolytic complexes, the unstable products such as Fe(OH)2+, Fe(OH)2 +, Fe3(OH)4 5+, and Fe2(OH)2 2+ initially formed might end up with the precipitation of a basic salts having probably a polymeric nature [29]. These might change the morphology and size of the precipitates. XRD patterns of calcined (fresh) and spent catalysts are given in Fig. 1 . In case of calcined catalysts, diffraction peaks at 2θ = 30.370, 35.50, 42.90, 53.60, 57.090, and 62.620, assigned to a cubic spinel phase of ZnFe2O4 (JCPDS card No. 22-1012), were observed for all catalysts [30]. The formation of ZnFe2O4 phase with a cubic franklinite spinel-type structure for Fe2O3–ZnO precursors with Zn/Fe atomic ratios of > 0.2 has been reported by Li et al. [13]. XRD patterns of all samples displayed broad peaks due to their small crystallite sizes. The poor diffraction peaks, one at 2θ = 33° and the other at 2θ = 20° were observed for some catalysts, the former for 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH-I), 2Fe.Zn (SC), and 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)3 and the latter for 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH-I). Peaks at 2θ = 33° and 2θ = 20° are characteristic peaks of α-Fe2O3 and ZnO crystal phases, respectively [31,32]. This suggests that these phases might form depending on the preparation routes alongside of zinc ferrite spinel phase. XRD patterns of spent catalysts were given in the supplementary document. Obviously there were some low intensity peaks in the XRD patterns of the spent catalysts that might be attributed to carbide species. As frequently reported in the literature, iron carbide is characterized by many peaks of low intensity. Abbas et al. [33] labeled the noise-like peaks in the range of 2Ɵ = ∼39-46° 2Ɵ in the spent zinc ferrite catalysts as Hagg iron carbide (Fe5C2) phases. In an another study by Yang et al. [34], the diffraction peaks at 2Ɵ = 39.31°, 40.83°, 43.40°, 44.08°, and 47.18° were assigned to Fe5C2 phase (JCPDS, NO. 51-0997). Janbroers et al. [35] gave insights into the nature of iron-based Fischer–Tropsch catalysts from in situ XRD analysis. A poorly crystalline iron carbide phase was characterized by diffraction lines at 2Ɵ = 39.2°, 41.0°, 43.5° 46.8°, 58.5°, and 67.7°. These results suggest that, XRD might not be an adequate technique for the accurate identification of iron carbide compounds in spent catalysts. Supplementary surface or in-situ characterization techniques like XPS, Mossbauer spectroscopy or in-situ XRD are needed to resolve this matter. XRD peaks of zinc ferrite weakened after reaction which might result from the formation of amorphous carbon layer or changes occurred in iron phases. Textural properties and crystallite sizes of catalysts are given in Table 3. Crystallite sizes were calculated by Scherrer Equation. Results revieled that the precipitation agent had a significant effect on the crystal size of zinc ferrite. Comparision of crystallite sizes of 2Fe.Zn(AH) and 2Fe.Zn(SC) clearly indicated that sodium carbonate produced smaller zinc ferrite crystals than ammonium hydroxide. The crystal growth can be induced by the precipitation agent in the solution where the size of nanoparticles can be modified by alkali concentration and ionic strength of aqueous medium [36]. Results of XRD analysis also showed that the crystal size of zinc ferrite was smaller than that of iron oxid. This suggests that zinc is a suitable structural promoter which could inhibit the growth of the iron oxide crystallite [24,37]. In the co-precipitation of zinc and iron salts, several parameters, such the counter ions, the ionic strength, pH, and precipitation temperature might affect the ultimate physicochemical properties of zinc ferrites [38,39], i.e., smaller aggregates are formed at high pH values due to the high nucleation rates compared to the crystals formed at a lower pH [40]. These results are in line with work of Knight and Sylva [41], who observed that the crystallites tended to become smaller with increase in basicity in the synthesis of catalysts prepared by precipitation. In this study, the type of the precipitant and ionic medium of hydrolysis were seen to impact the total surface area of zinc ferrite samples. The effect of ionic strength of the precipitation medium on the final zinc ferrite surface area was evident. For example, zinc ferrite with a higher surface area of 102 m2/g was obtained as a result of precipitation with sodium carbonate, 2Fe.Zn (SC). For 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH) and 2Fe.Zn0.4Na (AH) catalysts, precipitated in the presence of both sodium and ammonium ions, a significant increase in surface area was observed compared to 2Fe.Zn (AH) which was precipitated only in the presence of ammonium ions. While surface area of 2Fe.Zn (AH) was 77 m2/g, incorporation of sodium ion to the precipitation bath increased its surface area to 113 m2/g (2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH)). On the other hand, the total surface area of the catalysts decreased and their crystal size increased upon sodium impregnation. This phenomenon was obvious for 2Fe.Zn (SC), 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1, 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)2, and 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)3. Surface area and pore volume of 2Fe.Zn (SC), decreased from 102 m2/g to 25 m2/g and 0.18 cm3/g to 0.06 cm3/g, respectively when its sodium content was increased from 0.5 to 5.6% via impregnation. The SEM images, elemental mappings and EDS analysis of 2FeZn(AH) and 2FeZn(SC) were used for comparison whereas those for remaining were provided in supplementary. Fig. 2 shows SEM micrographs of 2Fe.Zn (AH) and 2Fe.Zn (SC) catalysts together with elemental mappings for iron and zinc. A rough zinc ferrite surface was distinguished, which was not plate-like. Although, the effect of the precipitation agent on the surface morphology was not very obvious, it was noticed that 2Fe.Zn(SC) looks like somewhat similar to an eroded sponge with some small holes and cavities. On the other hand, more smooth surfaces were more prominent for 2Fe.Zn (AH) catalyst. All catalysts with or without sodium based precipitant were calcined at 400 °C to avoid agglomeration. This is probably why smaller grains in less spherical morphology were obtained due to incomplete reaction between iron hydroxide and zinc hydroxide producing zinc ferrite. It is apparent from the combined evaluation of the bulk and the EDS chemical analyses that the catalysts precipitated without sodium had an iron content more than the stoichiometric amount of zinc ferrite structure. The Fe/Zn ratio of 2Fe.Zn(AH) varied in the range of 2.95–3.2 based on ICP or EDS analysis, while the Fe/Zn ratio of 2Fe.Zn(SC) was in the range of 1.75–1.85. These results suggest that other iron oxide compounds may be exist in 2Fe.Zn(AH), besides the zinc ferrite structure. Elemental mapping confirmed that the lumps observed in the SEM images were predominantly iron and zinc species. The results of TPR analysis of catalysts are presented in Fig. 3 . It shows the removal profile of lattice oxygen atoms from zinc ferrite in sodium free and sodium laden forms using H2 as the reductant. Three different reduction zones are distinguished in temperature regions of: 300–450 °C, 450–575 °C and 575–800 °C [42]. The peak centered at around 300–450 °C associates with the formation of magnetite phase (Fe2O3 → Fe3O4) while the second broad peak extending to 800 °C corresponds to the transition region from Fe3O4 to FeO [43]. Since FeO (wustite) is known to be unstable below 570 °C, α-Fe and Fe3O4 phases may also exist due to FeO disproportionation reaction. 2Fe.Zn(SC), 2Fe.Zn(AH), 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH), and 2Fe.Zn0.4Na (AH) displayed very similar TPR profiles. Their poor TPR peaks indicate that ZnFe2O4 is much more persistent to reduction compared to Fe2O3. Changing the ionic strength in the precipitation bath by simultaneous incorporating sodium and ammonium ions slightly decreased the initial reduction temperature of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 as seen in the profiles of 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH), and 2Fe.Zn0.4Na (AH) compared to 2Fe.Zn(AH). Since there is a significant difference between the solubility constant of Fe(OH)3 and that of Zn(OH)2, some Zn(OH)2 could partially be in dissolved phase while all Fe3+ ions were completely precipitated in the alkaline environment. Change in ionic strength may have an impact on this phenomenon. Therefore, we can consider the purity of ZnFe2O4 nanoparticles would be affected as noticed from altered TPR profile with changing alkaline environment. So dopant material, i.e. an alkali metal added by impregnation, can significantly modify the reduction behavior of the catalysts. This was observed in patterns of 2Fe.Zn (SC), 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1, 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)2, and 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)3 catalysts, all precipitated with sodium carbonate but containing different amounts of sodium. In the profile of 2Fe.Zn (SC) catalyst with least amount of sodium and the smallest iron oxide crystal size, the first peak is indistinct and its maximum occurred at around 330 °C. Similarly, the first peaks of 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1, 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)2, and 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)3 catalysts shifted to the right with their maximums displayed at 380 °C, 390 °C and 420 °C, respectively, in accordance with their increasing sodium content. These results are in agreement with that of An et al. [44] who investigated the effect of the residual sodium on the reduction and carburization behavior of iron based catalysts and observed that the first stage reduction peak shifted to higher a temperature with increasing the residual sodium content. This was claimed to be associated with the textural properties of the catalyst and was attributed to the changing iron oxide crystallite size in the presence of sodium. They also reported that surface areas of the catalysts decreased and the crystal sizes increased with increasing sodium concentration as a result of the poor dispersion. Since the reduction sequence can depend on the crystallite size and the crystallographic form for a given oxide, iron oxides in close contact with sodium may have different chemisorptive properties that may induce the reduction sequence. Therefore, the presence of three peaks observed in the TPR profile of 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)3 seems reasonable, which has the largest crystal size among the catalysts compared. The completion of the reduction reactions of 2Fe.Zn (AH), prepared with ammonium hydroxide (sodium-free precipitant), at lower temperatures than that of 2Fe.Zn (SC), prepared with sodium carbonate, also supports this argument. This may be due to sodium ions remained in the catalyst as previously discussed. These finding are in line with previous studies declaring that the preparation method of iron oxide catalysts can considerably affects their reduction behavior due to the different structural properties and morphologies [45]. The surface basicity exhibited by zinc ferrites with or without sodium impregnation was studied by CO2-TPD analysis. The results are shown in Fig. 4 . TPD peaks were observed in three different temperature zones: 100–150 °C, 350–525 °C, and 550–800 °C. Since the surface basicity of the catalysts mainly comes from Na2O attached to the catalyst surface, all sodium-impregnated catalysts appear to have an overall surface basicity. It is noteworthy that the zinc ferrite catalyst precipitated with ammonium hydroxide in the absence of sodium, 2Fe.Zn (AH), has shown slight surface basicity. Therefore, it would be helpful to explore first where the basicity of the catalysts without sodium comes from. As discussed by Yang et al. [16], the addition of Zn might bring some basicity due to the strong interaction between Zn and Fe in the lattice spinel structure as with 2Fe.Zn (AH). In the other side, the addition of sodium nitrate to the ammonium hydroxide precipitation bath did not increase the surface basicity, and even led to a lesser surface basicity. Less basicity of 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH) and 2Fe.Zn0.4Na (AH) compared to 2Fe.Zn (AH) may originated from the altered precipitation equilibria in the presence of additional sodium and nitrate ions. TPD peaks are more visible for sodium impregnated catalysts, 2Fe.Zn0.1Na (AH-I), 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH-I), 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1, 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)2 and 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)3. As reported in the literature [46], CO2-TPD desorption profiles of most basic metal oxides, such as magnesium or aluminum oxide, consist of three distinct basic groups: the weak basic surface OH groups, Lewis acid–base sites of medium strength, and low-coordination oxygen anions of strong basicity. The first groups are a kind of quite labile bicarbonate surface species formed on the surface hydroxyl groups [47]. The second groups may be ascribed to CO2 interaction with the surface basic sites likely through a variety of bidentate carbonates. They might display stability of different degrees due to the oxygen exchanging between adsorbed carbon dioxide and the surface of metal oxides [48,49]. Therefore, they may produce more than one peak. The third class might be unidentate carbonates requiring low-coordination O2 − anions as argued by Di Cosimo et al. [47] and Aziz et al. [46]. Evaluation of Fig. 4, noticeably indicates the surface basicity for all sodium-impregnated catalysts in all groups. A weak peak at around 100–150 °C is common for all catalysts and may be simply assigned to the labile bicarbonate species. As the amount of impregnated sodium increases, the high temperature peak, which is the indicator of the strongest surface basic sites, shifts to the right irrespective of the precipitating agent. As the number and strength of the surface basicity increase, the coke formation during FT reaction increases as well. In this regard, it is of interest to compare the results of 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH-I) and 2Fe.Zn0.2Na(SC-I)1 prepared with different precipitants but having nearly the same bulk sodium content. 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH-I) displayed more intense peak in the high temperature zone as seen in the figure. Its peak temperature is 690 °C while that of 2Fe.Zn0.2Na(SC-I)1 is about 633 °C. These differences may be attributed to different dispersion degrees of sodium species in the catalysts. Dispersions of the alkali metals seem to be influenced by the surface basicity [16]. The results suggest that 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH-I) has a better sodium dispersion than 2Fe.Zn0.2Na(SC-I)1. Although these two catalysts have similar chemical compositions, the amounts of carbon formed during their FT reactions were significantly different, 15.7% for 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH-I) and 2.2% for 2Fe.Zn0.2Na(SC-I)1 as reported in Table 2. Much higher coking tendency of 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH-I) in FT reaction process supports the argument that both the number and the strength of the basic sites may impact the coke formation. 3.2 Fischer-Tropsch to olefin performance of Na-promoted FeZn catalysts CO hydrogenation over sodium incorporated zinc ferrite catalysts was performed in a high pressure fixed-bed reactor with a continuous flow of H2/CO: 2/1 and a gas hourly space velocity of GHSV=2580 h−1 at 310 °C and 10 bar. The effect of precipitant agent and total sodium content of the catalysts on their Fischer Tropsch to olefin (FTO) activity, selectivity and stability were investigated. CO conversion after 30 h from the initiation of the reaction and the average values for selectivity are given in Table 4 . The CO conversion with time on stream (TOS) for the catalysts synthesized by ammonium hydroxide (AH) and sodium carbonate (SC) precipitants are given in Figs. 5 and 6 , respectively. The CO conversion decreased and coke formation increased with sodium content for the catalysts prepared with sodium carbonate precipitant except for 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1. As seen in Table 4, a 88.6% CO conversion with a 27.1% C2-C4 olefin, 13.8% C5+ and 28.7% methane selectivity were achieved for 2Fe.Zn(SC) having 0.5% sodium. An olefin to paraffin ratio of 0.9 was calculated this catalyst. On the other hand, with increasing the sodium content, CO conversion first increased to 97.4% for 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1 and then a rapidly decreased to 70.3 and 52.3% for 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)2 and 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)3, respectively. However, their selectivity profiles converged to a common level of ∼50% light olefin, ∼21% C5+ and ∼21% methane selectivity. As a result of improved olefin selectivity, olefin to paraffin ratio of the product stream increased to around 6-7. It is reasonable to explain the reduction in CO conversion with the concomitant increase in coke formation as a measure of improved CO dissociation activity resulting from the sodium content of the catalyst. An et al. [50] reported, deactivationfor an alkali content beyond an optimum level for K promoted catalysts. There are studies reporting that alkali cations suppress the secondary olefin hydrogenation and increase the chain growth probability. As explained by Herzog and Gaube [51], the strength of carbon monoxide adsorption is enhanced by the alkali compounds. This leads to facilitated 1-alkene desorption and reduced rate of consecutive hydrogenation and of isomerization of 1-alkenes into 2-alkenes. As widely reported in the literature, alkali cations act as an electron donor and provide an iron surface with high electron density. This, consequently, strengthens the CO adsorption and its dissociation. The inhibited re-adsorption of olefins and relatively lowered rate of hydrogen transfer are responsible for the observed high olefin selectivity [52–54]. Although the effects of structural promoters like zinc on the catalytic performance of iron catalysts were reported for the direct synthesis of light olefins [27], any systematic study, however, has not been reported on the relationship between sodium content, basicity and FT activity for zinc ferrite catalysts. Zhao et al. [27], in their study, used K2CO3, Na2CO3, (NH4)2CO3, and CO(NH2)2 as precipitants for syntjesisi of FeZn catalyst with Fe/Zn molar ratio = 1 in order to see the effect of alkali content left over the precipitate on product selectivity. In this study FeZn catalysts with a Fe/Zn atomic ratio of 2 (2FeZn) were prepared to end up with a zinc ferrite crystal structure. Moreover, the effect of ionic strength was evaluated for 2FeZn precipitation in the presence of NH4OH, NH4OH plus NaNO3 and Na2CO3 precipitation agents in an effort to understand the effect of ionic strength on the catalyst basicity and on its FT catalytic performance. The effect of precipitation agent on FT activity of the catalyst has also been evaluated in terms of solid basicity. As seen from the CO2-TPD graph, Fig. 4, the number of sites with moderate and strong basicity increases with sodium content from 2Fe.Zn (SC) to 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1 and 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)3. Since all these catalysts were prepared with the same precipitation agent, namely sodium carbonate, linearly varying basicity with the sodium content was expected. However, despite the increased basicity of 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1 compared to the base 2Fe.Zn (SC) catalyst, less coking and a higher and more stable CO conversion observed for it needs to be argued. Normally facilitated CO dissociation over basic sites provides a relatively high coverage of carbon species on the surface in relation with hydrogen. This leads to a decrease in the paraffin selectivity and/or chain termination rates due to deficiency of surface hydrogen [53]. Therefore, more favorable conditions may be established for the carbon formation. As discussed by van Santen et al. [54], catalytic surface becomes blocked with the accumulation of growing hydrocarbon chains due to the decreased hydrogen atom transfer in the chain growth termination reaction. Under this condition, CO conversion decreases as well since the lack of surface vacancies suppresses the rate of CO dissociation with time on stream. Therefore, there should be an optimum interaction strength of the surface where the rate of CO to CHx becomes balanced with the rates of chain growth and chain growth termination. As a plausible explanation, 2FeZn0.2Na (SC-I)1 might have an optimum amount of basicity and basic strength that ensures this balance. To highlight the importance of surface basicity, FT activity of 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH-I) and 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1 catalysts with the same sodium content but different basicity were compared in Table 4: A much lower CO conversion of 60.2% over 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH-I) was recorded compared to the value of ∼97.4% for 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1 catalyst. However, selectivity and the calculated olefin to paraffin ratios for these two catalysts were quite similar. A ∼ 47–50 % light olefin, ∼22% C5+ and ∼21% methane selectivity were obtained for them. Olefin to paraffin ratio of the product was ∼ 6. Although 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH-I) and 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1 contain nearly the same amount of sodium, it is not easy to explain why the basic site density of zinc ferrite precipitated with ammonium hydroxide, 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH-I), was much higher than that of 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1. Since the increase in the number of basic centers also affects the catalytic activity and stability, it is important to examine this effect. In a study by Dry and Oosthuizen [55], catalysts promoted with Li, Na, K, Ca, and Ba oxides were studied and surface basicity were correlated with their hydrocarbon selectivity in the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. They have argued that there was no such a relationship between the actual K2O content of the catalyst and its selectivity but there was a clear relationship between surface basicity and methane selectivity. They concluded that the surface basicity and hence the hydrocarbon selectivity depended not only on the amount of alkali but also on how well it is distributed over the catalyst surface. In this study, the higher number of basic sites of 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH-I) compared to 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1 was apparent from their CO2-TPD profiles although they had similar alkali content. This may suggest that the basic sites might be more dispersed over 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH-I) surface. Therefore, a surface with stronger tendency towards CO dissociation may be expected for 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH-I) catalyst due to the more basic sites available on its surface. As a result of this, much higher carbon content of the spent 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (AH-I) and its poor stability may be ascribed to its higher number of basic sites compared to 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1. 4 Conclusion Na-promoted Fe-Zn catalysts of zinc ferrite structure were used to produce light olefins (C2-C4) from syngas. In an effort to understand the effect of precipitant and solid basicity on Fischer-Tropsch activity, different synthesis methods with two different precipitants have been applied. As total alkalinity of precipitation affects hydrolysis and influences the composition of the intermediate hydrolytic complexes, the final features of metal hydroxide precipitates might be induced with the precipitation conditions. This was proved by the observed change on the textural properties such as total surface area, crystal size and morphology of zinc ferrites under different alkaline environment. Different TPR profiles of the catalysts with different basicity might be indicative of changing chemisorption properties depending on the catalyst crystallite size and morphology. Three distinct classes of basic groups affecting the catalytic activity and stability were noticed as well. Improved conversion due to the facilitated CO dissociation over basic sites and concomitant deactivation possibly through fouling might be interpreted as both the number of basic sites and strength were determinant on the final catalytic behavior. For all samples with certain amount of sodium, selectivity profiles approached to common levels, namely higher light olefin and C5+ selectivity at the expense of methane and paraffin selectivity. However, deactivation in the presence of alkali cations remains an important issue. The presence of less-coking catalysts despite basicity, such as 2Fe.Zn0.2Na (SC-I)1, suggests that there might be optimum levels for basicity and its strength. This might ensure a balance between the rate of CO dissociation and the rate of chain growth. Otherwise coking occurs due to the uncontrolled rate of hydrocarbon chain growth on the active sites. coredata.dc:description: The effects of precipitant and solid basicity on the Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS) activity of the sodium doped zinc ferrite catalysts were investigated. Olefin selectivity and stability of the catalysts were interrelated with the solid basicity which varied with the type of the precipitant, the amount of alkali promoter and its incorporation way into the catalyst matrix. The type of the precipitant and ionic medium of hydrolysis were seen to affect the textural properties of zinc ferrites. A cubic spinel phase of ZnFe2O4 were observed for all catalysts. Sodium promoter significantly modified the reduction behavior of the samples as well. Since the ionic strength was believed to have an effect on the solubility constants of Fe(OH)3 and Zn(OH)2, the purity of ZnFe2O4 nanoparticles would be expected to change as to be noticed from their different TPR profiles. All zinc ferrite samples had a much smaller crystal size than the precipitated iron, showing the structural promoter effect of zinc. In the study, the basicity of the catalysts was also correlated with FTS activity. All alkali promoted zinc ferrite catalysts have shown high olefin selectivity of about 50%. Although a basicity of certain extent is a must to attain high olefin selectivity, coking seems inevitable at high basicity. Therefore, an optimum interaction strength of the surface for CO dissociation appeared to exist and it might be tuned by surface basicity.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of sodium incorporation into Fe-Zn catalyst for Fischer- Tropsch synthesis to light olefins
